definitions.definition: Senses relating to a rolling motion.

subdefinitions.definition: To move (something, especially a round object ) by, or as if by, rolling ; to bowl , to roll, to trundle . [from 15th c.] ( obsolete ) Often followed by in : to cause (something) to flow or roll in like a stream .

To roll; also, to turn round and round ; to rotate , to spin , to whirl . [from early 15th c.] To move or walk at a leisurely pace ; to ramble , to saunter , to stroll . [from late 14th c.] ( specifically , slang ) Chiefly of a man : synonym of cruise ( “ to stroll about to find a ( male ) sexual partner ” ) . [from 20th c.] ( obsolete ) Followed by in : to flow or roll in like a stream.

definitions.definition: Senses relating to the motion of passing around.

subdefinitions.definition: To sing the parts of (a catch , round , or similar song ) in succession ; also ( generally ) , to sing (a song) freely or in a carefree way , or loudly . [from 16th c.] ( obsolete ) To pass (something, specifically a bowl or other communal drinking vessel ) from one person to another; to circulate , to send about.

Of bells : to ring a sequence of tones in a resounding manner . ( music , archaic ) Of a person: to sing the parts of a catch , round , or similar song in succession; also ( generally ) , to sing freely or in a carefree way, or loudly. ( music , archaic ) Of a song: to be sung freely or in a carefree way, or loudly; also, of a tune : to be constantly in someone's mind . ( obsolete ) Of a bowl or other communal drinking vessel, or the drink inside it: to be passed around from one person to another.

definitions.definition: Senses relating to a light, quick motion.

subdefinitions.definition: To say (something) lightly and quickly , or in a deep , resounding voice . ( obsolete ) To move (the tongue ) lightly and quickly when speaking .
To speak lightly and quickly, or in a deep, resounding voice. ( obsolete ) To move lightly and quickly; especially of the tongue when speaking; to wag .

To fish in (a place ) using a running fishing line (that is, a line with a hook on the end which is drawn along the water surface , possibly a line which would originally have been spooled on to a troll (etymology 2, noun sense 8.1 ) ). ( figurative ) To attract or draw out (someone or something); to allure , to elicit , to entice , to lure .
To fish using a running fishing line. ( fishing , Scotland , US ) To fish using a line and bait or lures trailed behind a boat similarly to trawling .

definitions.definition: Senses relating to "fishing" for a reaction.

subdefinitions.definition: To post irrelevant or inflammatory statements in an online discussion in an attempt to start a heated argument or to derail a conversation , either for one's personal entertainment or as part of an organized political campaign .
examples: Don't pay attention to that guy, he's always trolling this board.
When an argument gets heated, it can often be difficult to figure out who's serious and who's just trolling .

subdefinitions.definition: To persistently harass someone over the Internet .
examples: Many people have been trolling me due to my activism, but I don't let it get to me.

subdefinitions.definition: To prank , tease , or mess with someone in a lighthearted way.
examples: The actress was widely trolled online after accidentally revealing that she didn't know the names of the continents.

main_definition: Senses relating to a rolling motion.
secondary_definitions: Senses relating to the motion of passing around.
Senses relating to a light, quick motion.
Senses relating to "fishing" for a reaction.
